header.title: Liber Juratus or The Sworne Booke of Honorius
header.category: Grimoire, Western Esotericism, Angelic Magic, Ceremonial Magic

central_thesis: The "Liber Juratus" presents a divinely sanctioned system of high magic, revealed through the angel Hocroel to Honorius, enabling a purified Christian practitioner to safely invoke and constrain celestial, aerial, earthly, and infernal spirits. Its core aim is to achieve various thaumaturgical and practical effects (from finding hidden treasures to influencing natural phenomena and obtaining knowledge of past/present/future) for beneficial purposes, distinguishing its righteous practice from the "wicked" actions of negromancers. The legitimacy and efficacy of the art are tied directly to its sacred origins, the purity of the practitioner, and the meticulous consecration of its central artifact, the "Seal of God," using divine names and specially prepared blood.

structure_content.summary: This section narrates the origin story of the "Sworn Book." It describes a divine intervention to counter the corruption sown by wicked spirits, leading to the revelation of this art. The text critiques the misuse of magic by 'negromancers' but justifies its own existence by stating that spirits are naturally constrained by 'cleansed or clean' individuals. It details how Honorius, guided by the angel Hocroel, compiled 93 chapters from 7 volumes of 'art magic' to create this 'Sacred or Sworn Book,' emphasizing its divine consecration and the 100 sacred names of God it contains. The prologue concludes with the strict oath taken by masters to safeguard and responsibly transmit the book, restricting its access to only purified, godly, and faithful men.

This section provides a comprehensive table of contents, outlining the book's 93 chapters organized into four 'works.' The **First Work** (6 chapters) focuses on fundamental divine principles, including the 72-letter Schemhamphoras, vision of Deity, divine power, and redemption. The **Second Work** (27 chapters) details practical applications related to celestial mechanics, spirits (angels of heavens, air, fire, higher, water, earthly, infernal), influences of planets/stars, and natural forces (herbs, elements, man's nature, changing day/night). The **Third Work** (54 chapters) covers high thaumaturgical operations, such as constraining/shaping spirits, causing natural phenomena (thunder, snow, floods), invisibility, finding lost items, destroying kingdoms, creating illusions, healing/sickness, and influencing human affairs. Notably, chapters on appearing dead bodies and beasts were explicitly removed as 'against the will of God.' The **Fourth Work** (originally 5 chapters, with 2 removed) concerns delivering prisoners, locking castles, and finding hidden treasures.

This section serves as an introduction to the main operative text. It re-emphasizes the divine authority of the work, stating that its principles follow Solomon's precepts. It highlights that the efficacy of the art, and true invocation, stems from the 'very faith of the heart,' asserting that there is 'one only God, one mighte, or power, oone faythe,' from whom all perfection and effect derive. It also provides a crucial distinction regarding the suitability of practitioners, stating that only Christian men can work 'truely' to achieve the vision of the Deity and other effects, as Jews and Pagans lack the necessary 'sign of the cross' or true faith, making their works imperfect.

structure_content.chapter_title: [IV] Here follows the making of the Seal of the true and living God (De compositione signi dei vivi)
structure_content.summary: This is a detailed, step-by-step practical guide for constructing the central magical tool of the system: the 'Seal of God.' Instructions cover precise geometric drawing of concentric circles (with specific diameters like 3, 5, 7, or 9 fingers), a central pentagram, an inner tau cross, and two surrounding heptagons. The Seal must be inscribed with the 72-letter Schemhamphoras, specific divine names ('el,' 'ely,' 'lx,' 'al,' 'nm,' 'vm'), and a series of planetary angelic names (Casziel, Satquiel, Samael, Raphael, Anael, Michael, Gabriel), along with other divine names ('narath,' 'libarre,' 'veham,' 'yalgal,' 'vos,' 'duymas,' 'Gyram,' 'Gram,' 'Aysaram,' 'A,' 'Omega,' 'el,' 'ON,' 'Ely,' 'Eloy,' 'Christos,' 'Sother,' 'ADONAI,' 'Saday'). Coloration instructions for various parts (red with saffron, azure, purple, black, green) are also provided, along with the requirement that the Seal be drawn on virgin parchment using ink made from the blood of specific animals (mole, turtledove, lapwing, bat).

structure_content.chapter_title: [V] The beginning of the cleansing or purging of him who shall work in this art
structure_content.summary: This section outlines the stringent moral and ritual purity requirements for the practitioner. It mandates extreme penitence and truthful confession of all sins, complete abstinence from the company and enticements of women (citing Solomon), and avoidance of wicked or sinful men (citing David). The practitioner must lead a 'pure and clean life,' wear new or very clean apparel, and engage in constant prayer to avoid idleness and sin. These rigorous preparations are presented as fundamental to the art's efficacy and the safe constraint of spirits, ensuring the practitioner is 'clean from all filthiness of soul and body.'

This section provides detailed recipes for various incense mixtures ('suffumigations'), which are crucial for creating specific magical atmospheres and influencing spirits or energies. Recipes are categorized by planetary days (Saturday to Friday), specifying herbs, resins, and sometimes animal components (e.g., costus, musk, amber, lignum aloes, brains of eagle/raven, blood of white cock/black cat, sanguine menstruo). More complex suffumigations are detailed for general visions, expelling visions/fantasies, making houses appear full of water/blood, finding hidden things (requiring specific astrological timing with the Moon in the 4th house), and causing visions of the air or sepulchers. Additionally, suffumigations are prescribed for each of the 12 zodiacal signs and their three 'faces' (decanates), for specific hours of the day, and for the four elemental quarters of the world.

This section contains extensive lists of angelic names essential for the invocation and constraint of spirits within the system. It enumerates the angels associated with the seven days of the week (Capziel for Saturn, Satquiel for Jupiter, Samael for Mars, Raphael for Sun, Anael for Venus, Michael for Mercury, Gabryel for Moon), noting their planetary correspondences. It also lists angels of the Air (e.g., Ystana, Surail, Raphael, Guabriel, Michael, Cherubin, Seraphin) and Earth (e.g., Nyguedam, Yabassa, Samael, Yatayell, Baranyell), specified for different hours or operational purposes. Furthermore, comprehensive lists of 'Potentates' (princes/rulers) and angels are provided for each of the 12 (and sometimes 13) months of the year, with numerous names listed for each month (e.g., Oriel, Zaziel for Nisan; Amariel, Tabriell for Sivan; Daniel, Olyeill for the Sun-day, Semhazylin, Semyhylim for the Moon-day, etc.), indicating their role in specific temporal operations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Rite of exorcism of blood (CXXXVII 20-22) & Oration/Blessing
structure_content.summary: This critical ritual details the consecration of the blood used to write the 'Seal of God.' The practitioner must face Jerusalem (East) and recite a specific exorcism over the blood (adapted from a salt exorcism) three times, while wearing a stole. This process transforms the blood into a sacred medium. This is followed by a series of powerful prayers ('Orations' and 'Blessings') invoking the Holy Trinity, Holy Mary, and a vast array of divine names (including 'O Invisible God, O Inestimable God,' Joth, He, Vau, Daleth, Agla, Eloy, Yayin, Theos, Deus, On, Alpha and Omega, Sabaoth, Adonay, Egge, Ya, Ya, Ye, and 100 Holy Names). These invocations are intended to bless and sanctify the blood, imbuing it with divine power, making it a 'sacrament in writing' suitable for inscribing the Seal and ensuring the Sealâ€™s efficacy for all intended magical operations.

key_concepts.definition: A 72-letter name of God, central to the 'Seal of God' and the efficacy of the entire system. It is presented as the primary divine force enabling the art, and its letters are meticulously inscribed on the Seal.

The central magical artifact of the system. It is a complex geometric design (concentric circles, pentagram, heptagons, crosses) precisely inscribed on virgin parchment with divine names, angelic names, and the Schemhamphoras. Consecrated with purified blood, it acts as a focal point for divine power and a primary tool for spirit communication and control.

A strict moral and physical regimen required for the magician, encompassing penitence, confession of sins, abstinence from women and sinful company, leading a 'pure and clean life,' maintaining clean apparel, and constant prayer. This spiritual and physical purity is considered paramount for safely constraining spirits and ensuring the ethical and effective operation of the magic.

Specific incense mixtures, carefully compounded from various herbs, resins, and sometimes animal parts (e.g., brains, blood). These are prescribed for different planetary days, hours, zodiacal signs, and elemental quarters to create the correct magical atmosphere, attract specific spirits or energies, and facilitate particular operative effects like visions or phenomena.

The system distinguishes between celestial angels (e.g., Cherubin, Seraphin) who serve God directly and are not to be invoked by mortals, and other classes of spirits (aerial, earthly, infernal) that can be constrained. The book provides extensive lists of angels associated with planetary days, months, hours, and elemental realms, intended for specific invocations and operations.

The act of binding, compelling, and controlling spirits to perform the practitioner's will. This is a core mechanism of the magic, applied to aerial, earthly, and infernal spirits. The concept extends to the use of words, seals, and tables to achieve these bindings.

The foundational religious and moral prerequisite for the practitioner. The 'Liber Juratus' explicitly states that the magical system is effective only for Christians, as Jews and Pagans are said to lack the true faith and the 'sign of the cross,' rendering their magical efforts imperfect or even idolatrous.

The consecrated blood used to inscribe the 'Seal of God' is transformed into a 'sacrament' through specific exorcisms and divine invocations. This renders the physical Seal itself a sacred object, imbued with divine power and authority, which enhances its efficacy and protective qualities.

practical_system.description: The 'Liber Juratus' outlines a comprehensive system of ceremonial magic centered on the creation and activation of the 'Seal of God.' This Seal, meticulously constructed and consecrated with divinely empowered blood, serves as the primary instrument for communicating with and constraining various classes of spirits (celestial, aerial, earthly, infernal) to achieve a wide array of magical effects. The system places paramount importance on the practitioner's moral and spiritual purity, asserting that such righteousness is the foundation for safe, ethical, and effective operations. Through a combination of intricate ritual, divine names, angelic hierarchies, and planetary/elemental correspondences, the system provides a framework for advanced thaumaturgical and divinatory practices.
tools: **Virgin Parchment**: The required medium for creating the 'Seal of God.'
**Ink (Blood-based)**: Consecrated blood from specific animals (mole, turtledove, lapwing, bat) for inscribing the 'Seal of God.'
**Drawing Instruments**: For the precise geometric construction of the Seal.
**Stole/Scarf**: Worn around the neck during the blood exorcism ritual.
**New, Fingerless Gloves**: Used to handle the consecrated Seal, ensuring no profane contact.

**Suffumigation Ingredients**: A wide variety of herbs, resins, and sometimes animal parts (e.g., costus, thuris, mastic, musk, benjamin, storax, labdanum, amber armoniacum, folium mirti, sanders, cinnamon, cassia ligina, macis, nutmeg, cloves, orange/citrine rinds, mace, roses, violets, crocus, euphorbium, bedellium, armoniacum, helleborus, magnes stone, myrrh, sulphur, agate, lapis lazuli, black poppy, henbane, mandrake root, coriander, saffron, parsley, whale seed, cuttlefish gall, sweet gum).

**Knowledge of Celestial Correspondences**: Implied requirement for understanding astrological timings (planetary days/hours), zodiacal signs, and angelic hierarchies to properly apply suffumigations and conduct operations.
rituals: **Purification (Prima Mundatio)**: The practitioner must undergo rigorous spiritual cleansing, including penitence, confession, abstinence from women and sinful company, maintaining a 'pure and clean life,' wearing clean apparel, and engaging in constant prayer.

**Seal Construction**: Detailed geometric drawing of circles, a pentagram, and heptagons on virgin parchment. Inscription of the 72-letter Schemhamphoras, planetary angel names (Casziel, Satquiel, Samael, Raphael, Anael, Michael, Gabriel), and various divine/angelic names within specified areas. Precise coloring instructions for the various parts of the seal.

**Blood Consecration**: The blood (from a mole, turtledove, lapwing, or bat) used to inscribe the Seal must be consecrated through a specific exorcism. This involves facing Jerusalem (East), reciting a modified salt exorcism (replacing 'salt' with 'blood') thrice, and wearing a stole.

**Seal Blessing/Activation**: Reciting a series of powerful prayers and invocations over the consecrated blood/Seal. These prayers invoke the Holy Trinity, Holy Mary, and numerous divine and angelic names, transforming the blood into a 'sacrament in writing' and empowering the Seal for its intended purpose.

**Final Seal Placement**: After consecration, the Seal must be left overnight in the open air (clear sky). It is then placed into newly made, fingerless gloves (never touched by another hand) for its final accomplishment.

**Suffumigations**: The use of specific incense mixtures, carefully compounded according to planetary days, hours, zodiacal signs, and elemental quarters, to create the necessary energetic environment for specific operations (e.g., visions, spirit invocation/constraint, causing phenomena).

**Spirit Invocation/Constraint**: Utilizing the Seal's authority and specific angelic/divine names from extensive lists (planetary, monthly, daily, aerial, earthly) to summon and bind spirits for various purposes specified in the book's chapter list (though not fully detailed in the provided text).

relevant_quotes.text: When wicked spirits were gathered together, intending to send devils into the hearts of men, to the intent they would destroy all things profitable for mankind, and to corrupt all the whole world, even to the uttermost of their power...

...yet by this they shulde destroye all other scyences. It is thought right therefore to pluck up and utterly to destroy this deadly root, and all the followers of this art, but they through the instigation of the devil, and being moved with envy and covetousnes under the similitude of truth, they did publish and spread abroad the falsehood, speaking false and unlikely things. For it is not possible that a wicked and unclean man should work truely in this art, for men are not bound to spirits, but the spirits are constrained against their wills to answer men that are cleansed or clean, and to fulfill their requests.

...and he through the council of a certain angel whose name was Hocroel, did write seven volumes of art magic, giving to us the kernel, and to others the shells. Out of the which books he drew out 93 chapters, in the which is briefly contained the effect of this art, of the which chapters he made a book which we do call The Sacred or Sworn Book for this cause, for in it is contained the 100 sacred names of God, and therefor it is called sacred, as you would say 'made of holy things,' or else because by this book he came to the knowledge of sacred or holy things, or else because it was consecrated by angels, or else because the angel Hocroel did declare and show him that it was consecrated of God.

First, that this book should be delivered to no man until such time as the master of the art were in jeopardy of death, and...That it should be delivered to no woman, nor to any man except he were of lawful age, and he should also be both Godly and faithful, whose Godly behavior had been tried for the space of a whole year...
But these two chapters have we taken away, because they be against the will of God.

...The Christian man only works truely to come to the vision of the Diety, and in all other works. And although three sorts of men do work by this art magic, yet it is not to be thought that there is any evil in this name Magian, for this same name Magian signifies in the Greek tongue a philosopher, and in the Hebrew tongue a scribe, and in the Latin tongue it signifies wise. And so this name of art magic is compounded of this word magos which is as much to say as 'wise,' and of ycos which by interpretation is 'knowledge.' For by it a man is made wise. For by this art a man may know things present, past, and to come.

First he that shall work must be very penitent and truly confessed of all his sins. He must utterly forbear the company of women and all their enticements, insomuch that he may not look upon them. For as Solomon says, 'It is better to abide with a bear or a lion in their den than to be in a house with a wicked woman.'

Exorcizo te creatura sanguis + per deum vivum + per deum verum + per deum sanctum + per deum qui Salomonem in eius diuinam Sigillum primum in ssic: ut sanaretur sterilitas Sanguis efficiaris exorcizatum in salutem credentium: ut sis omnibus te sumentibus sanitas animae et corporis et effugiat atque disendat ab iste sanguine omnia samasia et nequitia vel versutia diabolicae fraudis: omnisquqe spiritus in mundus adiuratus per eum, qui venturus est iudicare vivos et mortuos et seculum per ignem. Amen.

God the Father bless you, God the Son bless you, God the Holy Ghost bless you. May Holy Mary mother of our Lord Jesus Christ bless and sanctify you, Oh blood, that you may have the might and power of a sacrament in writing of the Seal of God.

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Liber Juratus' is a foundational and highly influential grimoire within the Western Esoteric tradition, particularly in the Solomonic lineage. It uniquely frames itself as divinely sanctioned, distinguishing its 'holy' magic from 'wicked' necromancy through a rigorous system of practitioner purity and sacred ritual. Its detailed instructions for constructing the 'Seal of God,' precise angelic and divine name correspondences, and comprehensive suffumigation recipes offer invaluable insights into historical ceremonial magic practice. The text's explicit Christian framework and ethical self-justification are crucial for understanding the historical development of magic in Christian-dominated societies. It provides a blueprint for reconciling magical pursuits with religious doctrine, making it a key text for scholars and practitioners studying the evolution of grimoire traditions and the role of morality in magical systems.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The 'Liber Juratus' is intended for a highly dedicated, morally upright, and intellectually capable Christian practitioner. The stringent requirements for spiritual and physical purity (penitence, confession, abstinence, clean living), combined with the implied understanding of astrological and angelological correspondences, point to an audience of educated initiates. The oath of secrecy, forbidding its transmission to women or unproven men, further indicates its target as a select male fraternity or priesthood within a specific magical-religious context. It is not a casual manual but a profound and demanding system for advanced practitioners seeking to engage with the spirit world for significant, albeit ethically constrained, results.
